relevant_cases: 1828:Sagittal and axial post-contrast MR show a lobulated, heterogeneously enhancing pineal mass with subsequent multiple nodular leptomeningeal and ependymal enhancing deposits ("sugar-icing" pattern) — demonstrates typical CSF dissemination of pineoblastoma.;6806:Sagittal T1 and post-contrast images show an irregular, heterogeneously enhancing pineal mass that invades the tectum and extends through the aqueduct causing obstructive hydrocephalus — illustrates aggressive, infiltrative behavior of pineoblastoma.;16434:Non-contrast CT and post-contrast MR show a mildly hyperdense pineal mass with central calcification and avid, homogeneous enhancement — characteristic of germinoma and useful to distinguish from pineoblastoma which is usually heterogeneous and often lacks central calcification.;15105:Serial MR images show a cystic pineal lesion with nodular/thickened enhancing wall and interval growth — a pattern that can mimic pineoblastoma (cystic/necrotic malignant lesion) and emphasizes the imaging features that raise suspicion for pineoblastoma vs benign pineal cyst.;5483:CT and MR show a multiloculated heterogeneous pineal mass with areas of fat signal/low attenuation and calcification with fat droplets in subarachnoid spaces — classic for teratoma and helps exclude pineoblastoma which lacks macroscopic fat and typically shows homogeneous/heterogeneous solid enhancement and CSF dissemination.

8890:MRI shows a well-defined tenosynovial mass isointense to muscle on T1 with no susceptibility artifacts on GRE (absence of hemosiderin) and collagenous hypocellular histology — imaging pattern supports fibroma of the tendon sheath (FTS);1066:GCTTS case with low-intermediate signal on T1 and T2 attributed to hemosiderin and strong post-contrast enhancement — demonstrates imaging features (hemosiderin-related low signal and marked enhancement) that help differentiate GCTTS from FTS;18540:Localized tenosynovial giant cell tumour showing T1 hypointense mass, areas of signal drop on susceptibility/FFE (blooming from hemosiderin) and prominent enhancement — useful to exclude FTS when susceptibility artifacts are present;15087:Diffuse tenosynovial giant cell tumour (PVNS) with T1/T2 low-signal hemosiderin, bone erosions and enhancing synovium on MRI — these features (blooming, erosions) contrast with FTS and aid differential diagnosis;885:GCTTS example with low signal intensity on T1 and T2 due to hemosiderin deposition evident on MR images — reinforces that presence of hemosiderin/susceptibility favors GCTTS over FTS

12978:CT shows a large thin-walled multiloculated mesenteric cystic mass with thin enhancing septa and fluid attenuation (8-10 HU) matching the multiloculated appearance of lymphangioma.;6424:CT demonstrates a large lobulated thin-walled multicystic mesenteric mass with contents varying from water to fat attenuation and intimate bowel relation — imaging evidence of chylous/fatty content and multiloculation typical of lymphangioma.;19174:CT shows a multiloculated cystic mesenteric lesion with thin enhancing internal septa, lobulated borders, mass effect and complications (small-bowel obstruction, whirlpool sign) — illustrates how lymphangioma can present with inflammatory/complication-related changes and enhancing septa as in the target case.;8152:CT and MRI demonstrate a cystic mesenteric lesion with central fat density/signal and circular wall enhancement plus surrounding mesenteric inflammatory changes — directly supports chylous (fat) content and infection/inflammation in lymphangioma.;17202:Ultrasound and CT show an enteric duplication cyst with thick enhancing wall, ‘gut-signature’ (inner echogenic mucosa and outer muscular layer) and a shared wall with the duodenum — useful to distinguish duplication cyst from lymphangioma which lacks the gut wall signature.;5016:CT shows a cystic omental teratoma with fat-fluid level and calcified/solid Rokitansky protuberance — demonstrates imaging features (calcification/solid elements) that favour teratoma over lymphangioma and help exclude this differential.

9884:Pelvic MRI shows a well-circumscribed right adnexal mass with mixed solid and cystic architecture; solid component is intermediate on T1 and low–intermediate on T2 with scattered high-T2 areas — pattern and clinical androgen excess support androgen-producing Sertoli-Leydig cell tumour (matches target case imaging: solid/cystic, intermediate–high T2).;7243:Large heterogeneous predominantly solid ovarian mass with central cystic area and prominent feeding vessels converging to the hilum; enhancing solid capsule and internal enhancement on post-contrast MRI/CT — demonstrates the hypervascular, solid–cystic appearance typical of sex-cord stromal tumours and helps confirm vascular solid phenotype seen in SLCT.;10870:Well-defined solid ovoid ovarian mass with homogeneous low T1, central high T2 signal and a peripheral low-T2 rim with early avid peripheral enhancement — imaging pattern typical of sclerosing stromal tumour, useful to distinguish from SLCT by its characteristic peripheral low-T2 rim and early peripheral enhancement.;9059:Adnexal lesion with very low T2 signal focus on MRI (and mild delayed enhancement on post-contrast imaging) consistent with fibrous tissue (fibroma/thecoma) — this low-T2 fibrous signature helps exclude fibrous stromal tumours in the differential for an SLCT, which usually shows intermediate–high T2 signal.;13305:Heterogeneous solid adnexal mass with T1 and T2 signal similar to myometrium, internal cysts hyperintense on T2 and strong heterogeneous post-contrast enhancement — imaging of granulosa cell tumour that overlaps with SLCT features (solid/cystic, enhancing), highlighting the need for integration of imaging, age and hormonal findings to differentiate these entities.

11253:Pelvic MRI: bulky ovoid, homogeneous rectal mass with well-defined margins, diffuse concentric wall thickening, homogeneous post-contrast enhancement and marked diffusion restriction — imaging pattern consistent with rectal B-cell lymphoma and supports lymphoma over adenocarcinoma or GIST.;10587:CT/MRI: extensive concentric, homogeneous rectal wall thickening with smooth margins and minimal mesorectal invasion and diffusion restriction — pattern typical for rectal lymphoma (high cellularity) and helps distinguish from focal adenocarcinoma or GIST which are usually more heterogeneous and infiltrative.;15471:Rectal MRI: 3 cm submucosal lesion with low T2 signal, no gadolinium enhancement and low signal on high-b DWI — imaging typical of endometriosis (non-enhancing, T2-dark) and useful to exclude lymphoma which shows T2 hyperintensity, enhancement and diffusion restriction.;16138:MR and EUS: polypoid anorectal lesion with intrinsic high T1 signal (melanin), low T2 signal and diffusion restriction — imaging features characteristic of anorectal melanoma and help differentiate it from lymphoma (which does not show intrinsic T1 hyperintensity).;15210:Contrast-enhanced CT of gastric MALT lymphoma: diffuse homogeneous wall thickening with preserved fat planes and marked shrinkage after chemotherapy — demonstrates typical homogeneous involvement and chemo-responsiveness of MALT lymphoma, a pattern analogous to extranodal GI MALT including rectum.

17026:CT shows multiple bilateral isodense subcutaneous nodulations with surrounding fat stranding in the buttocks and US demonstrates the ‘snowstorm’ increased noise appearance consistent with free injected silicone/liquid filler — imaging pattern similar to subcutaneous oil bubbles.;13272:Neck US shows ‘cloudy’ high echogenicity with marked posterior enhancement (snowstorm sign) in supraclavicular node and silicone-specific MRI demonstrates high signal within the node; FDG-PET/CT shows metabolically active node — illustrates migration of injected silicone to nodes and imaging features that can mimic metastases, helping differentiate injected oil/silicone from true nodal metastasis.;16557:Mammography demonstrates multiple scattered linear and round high-density opacities in the breast and US shows extremely echogenic masses with dirty shadowing (snowstorm sign) — classic imaging of direct self-injection of silicone/fillers resembling subcutaneous oil nodules seen on CT/US.;16904:FDG-PET/CT reveals intensely FDG-avid calcifications within subcutaneous tissues at filler injection sites — demonstrates that injected fillers can be FDG-avid and mimic skin/soft-tissue metastases on PET/CT, an important differential when evaluating multiple subcutaneous nodules.;12579:Breast US and mammography of an oil cyst (post-traumatic fat necrosis) show a fat-containing oval mass with thin capsule, peripheral echogenic mural nodules and posterior acoustic enhancement — provides the classic ‘oil cyst’ appearance and helps distinguish organized oil-containing cysts from scattered free oil droplets or metastases.

11296:US shows lobulated hypoechoic soft-tissue mass with marked hypervascularity on power Doppler; MRI T1 hypointense/T2 hyperintense lesion with diffusion restriction and heterogeneous centripetal contrast enhancement (necrotic areas) and PET-CT hypermetabolism — imaging pattern strongly supports malignant small-round-cell tumour (extraskeletal Ewing sarcoma) rather than benign neurogenic lesion.;8549:Contrast CT shows an extrapulmonary paravertebral heterogeneously enhancing soft-tissue mass with no vertebral bone invasion — demonstrates extraskeletal presentation of Ewing sarcoma in soft tissues and differentiates from primary bone Ewing or benign nerve sheath tumours that typically show nerve-related morphology.;10781:Abdominal CT shows a solid, non-homogeneous mass with hypodense/necrotic areas and multiple peritoneal/omental implants and nodal disease — pattern of aggressive soft-tissue tumour dissemination consistent with extraskeletal Ewing sarcoma and helps exclude localized benign/vascular lesions.;17053:Thoracic CT demonstrates a large anterior mediastinal heterogeneously enhancing mass with cystic/hemorrhagic areas and heterogeneous enhancement — indicates aggressive soft-tissue sarcoma (extraskeletal Ewing) in an atypical location and helps distinguish from homogenous lymphoproliferative or purely cystic germ cell lesions.

18427:Perirenal capillary haemangioma: CT and MRI show a well-circumscribed nodule with peripheral hyperenhancement that persists into the portal phase and a T2-hyperintense centre (target-like appearance) with a feeding vessel — imaging pattern matches the peripheral/persistent enhancement seen in renal haemangioma (and similar to case 11532) and supports a diagnosis of vascular/Blood-filled lesion.;17989:Renal anastomosing haemangioma: small (1 cm) intrarenal nodule that is isodense to the blood pool across arterial and parenchymal phases with vivid homogeneous arterial enhancement — demonstrates that renal haemangiomas can be intensely hypervascular and may mimic RCC; recognition of isodensity to blood pool and early enhancement helps identify a vascular haemangioma variant.;10070:Giant cavernous hepatic haemangioma: classic peripheral globular/nodular enhancement with progressive centripetal fill-in on multiphase CT and eventual uniform enhancement — exemplar of the canonical haemangioma enhancement pattern (peripheral nodular enhancement with centripetal fill-in) that supports interpreting peripheral nodular/persistent enhancement in renal lesions as haemangioma rather than cystic neoplasm or abscess.;18088:Solitary fibrous tumour of the renal sinus (contrast): lobulated, solid renal sinus mass with relatively homogeneous attenuation and no peripheral nodular enhancement or persistent peripheral rim — useful as a negative comparator to distinguish haemangioma (which shows peripheral nodular/persistent or target-like enhancement and high T2 signal) from other renal-sinus tumours that enhance homogeneously.

17121:CT shows a thick-walled blind-ending tubular structure arising from the distal ileum separate from a normal appendix, with surrounding fat stranding and mesenteric lymphadenopathy — classic imaging for Meckel's diverticulitis and distinguishes it from appendicitis.;11923:Contrast-enhanced CT demonstrates a localized fluid collection adjacent to thickened small bowel and reactive mesenteric changes consistent with an inflamed Meckel's diverticulum (surgically confirmed). The focal collection and adjacent bowel wall thickening support the diagnosis.;17257:CT shows a fluid-filled distended structure at the distal ileum with an avidly enhancing intraluminal nodule (gastric heterotopia) and transition point; operative findings of torsion/strangulation confirm Meckel's — illustrates presentation with obstruction and heterotopic mucosa.;9137:Ultrasound demonstrates a mass connected to small bowel with alternating echotexture, hyperechoic mesenteric fat and prominent mesenteric nodes, which at surgery proved to be a perforated Meckel's diverticulum — shows sonographic features that can mimic intussusception but are pathognomonic when a neck to small bowel is seen.;14495:CT shows a rounded fluid collection with air-fluid level and faecal material near the ileum with minimal fat stranding; differential included ruptured appendix vs Meckel's, with surgery confirming strangulated Meckel's diverticulitis — demonstrates how Meckel can mimic appendiceal abscess on CT.

9848:Large lumbosacral intradural extramedullary mass isointense on T1, hyperintense on T2, with intense post-contrast enhancement and T2* hypointense foci (intratumoral haemorrhage) plus vertebral scalloping and craniospinal dissemination — imaging features of myxopapillary ependymoma that support the diagnosis in the target case.;16402:Well-defined tubular/sausage-shaped long-segment intradural extramedullary lesion within thecal sac that is T2 hyperintense and shows intense homogeneous enhancement, compressing cauda equina — matches the sausage-shaped enhancing L2-L3 lesion in the target and supports ependymoma.;11446:Lumbosacral T2-hyperintense, heterogeneously enhancing mass with sacral extension and posterior vertebral scalloping/foraminal expansion — demonstrates aggressive lumbosacral ependymoma imaging pattern useful for confirming ependymoma and contrasting features (scalloping) absent in target.;13239:Intraforaminal cystic lesion with neural foraminal widening and peripheral/ring-like enhancement consistent with schwannoma — provides imaging features that help differentiate nerve-sheath tumour from central intradural ependymoma in the differential diagnosis.

15169:Arterial-phase CT shows a curved tubular air-density structure that disappears on portal-phase imaging — example of a transient intraluminal imaging artefact that resolves on repeat acquisition, analogous to the colonic segmental spasm in the target case which vanished after further distension and hypotonisation.;12572:Water-enema CT colonography demonstrates a fixed 6-cm stricturing sigmoid carcinoma with circumferential enhancing mural thickening, abrupt shouldering proximally and distally, and persistent upstream faecal loading — shows the imaging pattern of true malignancy that can mimic spasm but does NOT resolve on repeat acquisition, helping to differentiate carcinoma from transient spasm.;10189:WE‑MDCT shows a rigid, poorly distended descending colon with moderate circumferential enhancing wall thickening, pseudopolyps and pericolonic fat hyperaemia (comb sign) — an inflammatory/fibrotic pattern causing persistent poor distension that helps distinguish chronic disease from transient segmental spasm artifact.;16556:CT colonography cases show smooth, plate-like pin‑hole strictures and focal luminal narrowings (NSAID diaphragm disease) that are unchanged on interval imaging/endoluminal reconstructions — an example of fixed strictures that can mimic focal non‑distension but are persistent, unlike transient spasm.;16038:CTC virtual endoscopy demonstrates multiple broad-based polypoid-appearing lesions that correspond to gas‑filled intramural cysts (pneumatosis coli) — an intraluminal mimic on CTC distinguished by intramural gas and lack of mural enhancement or shouldering, unlike spasm artifact.;2757:Barium enema shows a long narrow, stiff tubular colon with a ‘string sign’ from muscular spasm and fibrosis in ulcerative colitis — illustrates how muscular spasm (chronic/fibrotic) can produce severe luminal narrowing, but the chronic rigid appearance and flattened haustra help distinguish it from the transient, reversible segmental colonic spasm seen in the target case.

13341:Large heterogeneous retroperitoneal soft-tissue mass on CT with abundant intratumoural tortuous vessels and progressive enhancement; compresses but does not invade adjacent organs — imaging pattern consistent with NRSTS (malignant fibrous histiocytoma) and supports diagnosis of retroperitoneal NRSTS.;9046:Large retroperitoneal mass on CT with heterogeneous soft-tissue attenuation but with macroscopic fatty areas (fatty attenuation) and septations — imaging appearance diagnostic of dedifferentiated liposarcoma, an important differential to exclude when considering NRSTS (presence of macroscopic fat helps distinguish liposarcoma from NRSTS).;12705:Pediatric adrenal-origin masses on US/MRI with vessel encasement and metastatic liver nodules; classic features for neuroblastoma including adrenal location and vascular encasement — imaging features that help differentiate neuroblastoma from NRSTS in children.;16458:Well-defined, rounded-oval fluid-attenuating mass on CT occupying the greater omentum/mesentery with thin septations and lack of aggressive vascular encasement — imaging features compatible with mesenteric desmoid/benign cystic lesion, which helps distinguish noninfiltrative cystic masses from aggressive heterogeneous NRSTS.

18473:Shoulder MRI shows focal suprascapular nerve enlargement and T2 hyperintensity at the suprascapular notch with acute muscle oedema and chronic fatty atrophy of supraspinatus/infraspinatus — demonstrates the MRI pattern of denervation (acute STIR/T2 hyperintensity followed by chronic T1 fatty replacement) analogous to selective abductor digiti minimi fatty replacement in Baxter neuropathy.;19235:Pelvic MRI demonstrates obturator nerve thickening and T2 hyperintensity where the nerve is encased by iliac adenopathy, with oedema in obturator-innervated muscles and secondary mild fatty atrophy — an example of peripheral nerve entrapment producing selective muscle denervation and fatty replacement, matching the mechanism in Baxter neuropathy.;9784:MR shows increased T2/STIR signal (muscle oedema) and T1 hyperintense fatty infiltration/atrophy of muscles supplied by the anterior interosseous nerve — a clear example of focal motor denervation causing selective fatty muscle replacement, supporting interpretation of abductor digiti minimi fatty change as neurogenic.;19012:High-resolution US and MR demonstrate a well-defined, encapsulated lipomatous mass enveloping the tibialis anterior tendon with homogeneous high T1 signal, internal septations and complete fat suppression on PD-FS — imaging features that distinguish an encapsulated lipoma from diffuse neurogenic fatty muscle replacement and help exclude intramuscular lipoma as a cause of abductor digiti minimi change.

11221:CT shows circumferential homogeneous wall thickening of the 2nd–3rd parts of the duodenum (~1.6 cm) with para‑aortic adenopathy — direct match to duodenal lymphoma imaging (long segment, homogeneous, hypovascular duodenal mass).;18130:CT/US show long-segment, hypodense hypovascular circumferential bowel wall thickening of the terminal ileum with ileocolic and para‑aortic adenopathy, restricted diffusion on DWI and FDG uptake; marked response to chemotherapy — demonstrates typical lymphoma features (bulky, homogeneous, nonobstructing, chemo‑sensitive) that help distinguish lymphoma from adenocarcinoma or inflammatory disease.;10338:CT shows a focal/stenosing, irregular enhancing mass of the 3rd portion of the duodenum causing luminal narrowing — pattern more typical of adenocarcinoma (focal, stenosing, irregular) and useful as a differential comparator to lymphoma which tends to be long-segment and homogeneous.;11683:MRCP/CT/PET show circumferential soft‑tissue thickening at the porta/ampullary region causing CBD stricture with local lymphadenopathy and FDG avidity; biopsy-proven diffuse large B-cell lymphoma — illustrates how lymphoma can present with obstructive jaundice mimicking cholangiocarcinoma/ampullary tumour, directly relevant to the target case.

16976:Cortical-based lesion with central cystic component and intralesional hyperdense foci (calcifications) and superficial location adjacent to cortex — imaging pattern (cystic cortical mass with calcification) overlaps with PXA features seen in the target case (superficial cysts, calcified/hemorrhagic components).;18319:Large predominantly cystic frontal mass with an enhancing solid mural nodule and intralesional calcifications on SWI, with restricted diffusion in the solid nodule — demonstrates the classic cyst + enhancing mural nodule morphology and calcification that is characteristic of PXA and helps differentiate from purely diffuse gliomas or DNET.;10491:Cystic lesion with a vividly enhancing mural nodule that has a pial base and high rCBV on perfusion — illustrates the mural-nodule architecture and pial/leptomeningeal surface origin seen in PXAs (superficial cortical/pial-based tumors), useful as a morphological exemplar even though the pathology differs.;18963:Cortical/subcortical frontal lesions with coarse gyriform calcification and light bone remodelling/scalloping on CT, T2/FLAIR cortical hyperintensity and only minimal linear enhancement — shows bone remodeling/scalloping and cortical calcification features that support a superficial cortical tumour (like PXA) and help distinguish PXA from deep white-matter gliomas.

9553:Axial contrast-enhanced CT shows a well-defined left paravertebral mass with rough central calcification and homogeneous, avid contrast enhancement — matches the target case's posterior mediastinal, hypervascular appearance and helps distinguish from necrotic lymphoma or cystic neurogenic tumours.;16700:CT and MRI demonstrate a large, well-defined soft-tissue mass in the neck/upper mediastinum with bright T2/STIR signal and homogeneous (mild) post-contrast enhancement and PET avidity; shows unicentric Castleman can present as an isolated hypervascular mediastinal/neck mass that may encase but not infiltrate adjacent vessels, aiding differentiation from aggressive malignancies.;1882:MR images show a well-circumscribed paracardiac/pleural enhancing mass with heterogeneous T2 hyperintensity arising from pleura — demonstrates that unicentric hyaline-vascular Castleman can present as an encapsulated mediastinal/paracardiac mass and mimic pleural/neoplastic lesions, supporting the differential for the target posterior mediastinal mass.;19020:Contrast-enhanced CT of an isolated paraduodenal lesion shows avid homogeneous enhancement and a focus of internal calcification; endoscopic ultrasound shows a hypoechoic solid lesion and histology confirms hyaline-vascular Castleman. This case highlights solitary, avidly enhancing lymphoid mass with possible central calcification seen in unicentric Castleman disease, paralleling imaging features of the target mediastinal lesion.

15389:TVUS and contrast-enhanced CT show tubular multiloculated adnexal collections with fluid/fluid layering, thick hypervascular septa and thick-enhancing walls — imaging classic for pyosalpinx/tubo-ovarian complex (TOA).;10362:Transvaginal US and contrast-enhanced CT demonstrate an 8-cm multiloculated adnexal complex mass with thickened peripheral wall and contrast-enhancing septa — features typical of tubo-ovarian abscess; adjacency to inflamed sigmoid colon shows secondary TOA from diverticulitis.;9865:Contrast-enhanced CT shows a parauterine fluid collection with internal air and surrounding fat stranding adjacent to sigmoid diverticulitis — presence of internal gas within adnexal collection and inflammatory change strongly supports abscess (tubo-ovarian abscess) rather than neoplasm.;10088:Contrast-enhanced CT shows a fluid-containing tubular adnexal structure with enhancing walls, associated peritoneal enhancement/ascites and an IUD — imaging pattern consistent with pyosalpinx/tubo-ovarian abscess and severe PID.;11883:Multicystic adnexal masses with thick contrast-enhancing walls and marked peritoneal thickening/ascites on CT/MRI can mimic TOA; associated pulmonary nodules and necrotic mediastinal nodes and preserved normal ovaries in this case indicate pelvic tuberculosis — useful differential-imaging features to distinguish TB from TOA.

14120:Contrast-enhanced CT angiography shows a lobulated saccular pseudoaneurysm disrupting the basal anterior interventricular septum with a visible defect and direct communication between the LV cavity and the RV — demonstrates how post‑MI septal rupture/pseudoaneurysm appears as a contrast‑filled septal defect connecting ventricles.;18238:ECG-gated CT shows a clearly visualized subaortic ventricular septal defect (~2.7 cm) on coronal/sagittal reformats — provides anatomic example of an intracardiac septal defect and its location for comparison with post‑infarction septal rupture morphology.;18025:Pulmonary‑arterial phase CT demonstrates isolated early enhancement of the left ventricular outflow tract consistent with contrast passage through a reopened VSD (right‑to‑left shunt) — shows the contrast timing/early enhancement sign used to detect intracardiac shunts after infarction.;13386:Emergency MDCT shows high‑attenuation haemopericardium and contrast extravasation through a full‑thickness discontinuity of the LV free wall into the pericardial sac — exemplary imaging of free‑wall rupture and haemopericardium to differentiate from interventricular septal rupture, which produces intracardiac communication rather than pericardial extravasation.;9496:Non‑ECG gated CT after penetrating trauma demonstrates dense heterogeneous pericardial effusion (~50 HU) and linear high‑density contrast tracking into the pericardial sac anterior to the RV apex consistent with myocardial perforation and active extravasation — a trauma example of free‑wall rupture/perforation to contrast with septal rupture imaging features.

12226:Pelvic fluid collection is partially opacified on delayed/excretory-phase CT (higher attenuation within collection) with a visible track of contrast from the right distal ureter into the collection — classic CT-urography demonstration of iatrogenic ureteral leak/urinoma after pelvic surgery.;9710:Perinephric/retroperitoneal fluid collection shows marked increased attenuation on excretory-phase CT consistent with extravasated opacified urine; 3D reformations show relationship to collecting system — demonstrates how delayed imaging identifies urinoma and differentiates it from abscess/seroma.;12181:Medial perirenal extraluminal opacified urine originating at the ureteropelvic junction on excretory-phase CT with opacified proximal ureter — example of ureter/UPJ disruption causing urinoma and how delayed phase localizes injury level.;9613:CT urography shows clear extravasation of iodinated contrast from both ureters into a large retroperitoneal fluid collection (urinoma) with progressive increase in attenuation on delayed images — demonstrates direct visualization of contrast leak and extent of urinoma.;12239:Delayed excretory-phase CT shows opacification of the vagina (and tract) from the urinary bladder/ureteral system indicating a urinary fistula; useful to distinguish vesicovaginal or uretero-vaginal fistula versus urinoma and to localize source of urinary leak after pelvic surgery.

16525:Ultrasound shows transverse view of uterus with two distinct cavities (cornua), separate gestation in right horn and IUD in left horn - distinguishes bicornuate uterus (separate cavities with independent contents) from septate uterus (thin central septum with shared amniotic sac and fetus crossing septum);14563:Ultrasound shows two completely separate uterine horns each with own endometrial cavity without communication; MR shows widely divergent horns with fundal cleft >1 cm - differentiates complete duplication/didelphys from partial thin avascular septum in septate uterus;10893:Pelvic ultrasound demonstrates complete separation of uterine body into two parts with distended right endometrial cavity - illustrates didelphys complete separation vs partial thin septum allowing amniotic sac occupancy in both hemicavities;18804:USG shows thin hypoechoic myometrial layer surrounding gestational sac in rudimentary horn with no continuity to cervix/endometrial cavity, separate from main uterus - differentiates thin rudimentary horn wall from central avascular uterine septum with placental implantation and fetus parts crossing

2185:US shows solitary hypoechoic mass with posterior acoustic shadowing in diabetic mastopathy (sclerosing lymphocytic lobulitis), sharing mass-like hypoechoic presentation and fibroinflammatory pathology similar to IgG4-RD, with corresponding mammographic focal density unlike suspicious distortions.;14144:US reveals multiple hypoechoic masses with smooth-indistinct margins, internal echoes, connected tubular structures, and peripheral vascularity on Doppler in granulomatous mastitis, differentiating from target solitary well-defined lobulated lesion with minimal internal vascularity.;15270:US demonstrates well-defined oval heterogeneous hypoechoic mass with lobulated contours, mild cystic changes, and internal vascularity on Doppler; mammogram shows encapsulated lobulated isodense mass, mirroring target well-defined lobulated hypoechoic morphology but larger size helps contextualize benign differentials.;18097:US depicts well-defined oval hypoechoic mass ~20mm with small cystic spaces and no vascularity on color Doppler, highly similar to target superficial polylobulated hypoechoic lesion with minimal vascularity; mammogram well-defined ovals, confirming benign inflammatory imaging overlap in granulomatous mastitis.;4240:US of phyllodes tumors shows hypoechoic lobulated lesions with smooth margins, small cystic-like spaces, and posterior enhancement, confirming lobulated hypoechoic contour as feature of benign breast masses like target IgG4 lesion.;17775:US shows ill-defined diffuse heterogeneously hypoechoic area with mammo irregular ill-defined opacity and MRI segmental non-mass enhancement with DWI restriction, contrasting target discrete well-defined nodule to differentiate more infiltrative granulomatous mastitis.

17028:Enhanced axial CT shows enlarged left kidney with multiple hypodense dilated calyces (bear paw sign), some with air-fluid levels, staghorn calculus on topogram and coronal CT, perinephric fluid collections adjacent to thickened colon - confirms classic imaging of diffuse XGP with parenchymal destruction and perirenal extension as in target.;18308:Contrast-enhanced CT demonstrates bear paw sign with multiple hypodense rounded dilated calyces radially arranged in shrunken kidney, staghorn calculus, perinephric fat stranding, renal fascia thickening, fistula - shares bear paw sign and calyceal dilatation distinguishing from simple hydronephrosis.;17200:CT reveals enlarged left kidney with staghorn calculus, markedly thinned hypoenhancing renal parenchyma, hypodense collections in calyces, no excretion on delayed phase, ureter wall thickening - matches target nonfunctional kidney with parenchymal loss and stone.;17779:Non-contrast CT shows extensive peri-renal fatty expanse with staghorn calculus, enlarged kidney with mild calyceal ectasia; MRI confirms lipid-laden macrophages (in/out phase signal drop) and radial striae - highlights xanthogranulomatous lipid replacement distinguishing from renal tumor.;14129:Unenhanced CT: thinned parenchyma with confluent water-attenuation cavities and staghorn lithiasis; CECT: poorly enhancing thinned parenchyma, enlarged kidney compressing perirenal spaces - exemplifies calyceal dilatation and destruction in XGP vs pyonephrosis.;2523:CT shows staghorn calculus with extensive lipomatous perirenal/ sinus expansion, cystic spaces with fluid-debris levels on MRI, thin hypointense parenchyma rim - diffuse advanced form confirming chronic destructive process with perinephric involvement.

2185:Mammography demonstrates focal parenchymal condensations in the upper outer quadrant (arrows in Image 1) corresponding to palpable lump, matching the target case UOQ asymmetry; ultrasound shows hypoechoic masses with posterior acoustic shadowing (Image 2), similar to target hypoechoic palpable mass with indistinct margins and no vascularity, confirming typical imaging features of diabetic mastopathy (synonymous with lymphocytic mastopathy);8545:Focal asymmetry of density in upper left quadrant on mediolateral oblique mammogram (Image 1), akin to target asymmetry; ultrasound reveals ill-defined markedly hypoechoic area with slight posterior acoustic attenuation (Image 3) underlying palpable mass, directly comparable to target hypoechoic indistinct mass; normal MRI with no enhancement supports benign etiology distinguishing from carcinoma;14178:Mammography shows focal asymmetric densities in upper-outer quadrant (Image 1); ultrasound depicts areas of strong acoustic shadowing without definable masses (Image 3), resembling target large hypoechoic indistinct area; follow-up stability reinforces concordance with benign lymphocytic mastopathy;12236:Mammography exhibits moderate density nodule with ill-defined contours upper outer quadrant (Images 1-2); US confirms hypoechoic nodule with indistinct margins 3cm (Image 3), matching target imaging; follow-up mammogram shows resolution (Image 5), consistent with target resolution post-treatment;17489:Focal asymmetry upper central left breast on mammography (Images 1-2); ultrasound shows irregular hypoechoic mass 2.1cm with dense posterior shadowing and no hypervascularity (Images 3-4,6), mirroring target hypoechoic palpable mass indistinct margins no vascularity in diabetic mastopathy context;16604:Global asymmetry on mammography (Images 1-2) and multiple irregular hypoechoic nodules with indistinct margins on ultrasound (Images 5-7), plus non-mass heterogeneous infiltrative enhancement on MRI (Images 8-14); contrasts with target single large non-mass enhancement without multiplicity/infiltrative pattern or restricted diffusion, aiding differentiation from lymphocytic lymphoma

7657:Non-contrast CT demonstrates gas locules and hyperdense linear structure (chicken bone) between descending aorta and esophagus, with contrast-enhanced CT showing active contrast leakage into the interspace, directly analogous to the target case's periaortic gas bubbles and contrast extravasation into gastric fundus confirming aortoesophageal fistula;14192:Contrast-enhanced CT arterial phase shows multiple air bubbles (white arrowheads) within the mural thrombus of the stented descending thoracic aorta aneurysm, with adjacent huge gastric blood clot, mirroring intramural air and hematoma from fistula in target case;4124:CT images reveal a focal aortic wall irregularity/outpouching in the descending aorta adjacent to a mediastinal fluid collection/abscess with gas?, highlighting the fistulous communication similar to target's saccular aneurysm with periaortic gas;9603:Contrast-enhanced MDCT depicts large aberrant right subclavian aneurysm with small air bubbles within the thrombotic lumen adjacent to the posterior esophageal wall, identical imaging feature of intramural/peri-aneurysmal air indicating esophageal fistula as in target;5363:Unenhanced and enhanced CT show saccular aneurysm of distal descending thoracic aorta due to penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer with enhancing wall thickening and bulge but no intramural gas or contrast extravasation, distinguishing PAU (differential) from progressed AEF with fistula signs in target case;12642:CT-angiography demonstrates active contrast extravasation (arrows) from abdominal aortic aneurysm into the duodenum with distended blood-filled stomach, illustrating enteric fistula pattern but differentiates by abdominal location and bowel involvement versus thoracic esophageal in target

13885:MRI T1 mildly hyperintense multilocular cystic lesion seg IV with enhancing septa; hepatobiliary phase shows contrast accumulation in lesion indicating bile duct communication, directly analogous to target case US/MRI features of porta hepatis cyst with duct communication;6406:CT multiphase shows 43x44mm seg IV lesion, slightly lobulated well-defined, thin internal medial septation, hypodense non-enhancing (50HU density suggesting mucinous/proteinaceous content matching target high T1 signal), confirms imaging of mucinous biliary cystadenoma;11744:MRI depicts large hilar cystic mass (seg IV-VII-VIII) with internal septa and papillary vegetations avidly enhancing post-gadolinium, thick irregular wall, differentiates cystadenocarcinoma malignant features from target benign unilocular thin wall minimal enhancement;9127:US large hypoechoic cystic right lobe mass with dense fluid; CT huge well-defined cystic mass few irregular thin internal septations rare wall calcifications with moderate wall/septa enhancement, exemplifies mucinous hepatobiliary cystadenoma entity similar histology to target;18211:US subcapsular seg IVa hypoechoic cyst thin septa mobile echogenic contents; MRI lobulated T2 hyperintense predominantly T1 hypointense no restricted diffusion no enhancement, distinguishes ciliated foregut cyst from target by peripheral location echogenic debris T1 signal no duct comm

10251:CTA arterial phase MIP reconstructions clearly demonstrate anomalous arterial branch originating from the descending thoracic aorta supplying the postero-basal left lower lobe consolidation, with surrounding hypodensity mimicking emphysema visible on lung window axial CT - nearly identical imaging features to target case confirming pulmonary sequestration;6860:MPR reconstructions show anomalous vessel arising from descending aorta supplying left lower lobe consolidation with adjacent compensatory hyperinflation, matching the key systemic arterial supply and parenchymal abnormality in the target case;16797:Contrast-enhanced CT axial images depict heterogeneous mass (soft tissue, cystic areas) in medial basal left lower lobe supplied by large calibre systemic artery directly from descending thoracic aorta, sharing location, morphology, and diagnostic vascular feature with target;8153:CTA MIP and axial images reveal anomalous artery from descending thoracic aorta to multi-loculated cystic lesion with air-fluid levels in basal left lower lobe, exemplifying cystic sequestration variant with identical aberrant vascular supply;3184:CT coronal and axial views illustrate enhancing solid/cystic left lower lobe lesion fed by anomalous systemic artery, confirming the hallmark vascular finding of pulmonary sequestration seen in target case images;9442:Contrast-enhanced CT shows feeding artery from abdominal aorta to multicystic lower lobe lesion, distinguishing sequestration-associated cases from pure CPAM (differential) by presence of systemic arterial supply observable on vascular images

7137:US images demonstrate multiple serpiginous tubular anechoic structures (dilated ducts) admixed with echogenic stroma and prominent vascular flow on power Doppler, mirroring the target case s lactating ectopic axillary breast tissue features;11598:US shows heterogeneous axillary soft tissue with hypoechoic glandular elements intermixed with echogenic fat, characteristic of accessory breast glandular tissue without the prominent dilated ducts but confirming ectopic location;16605:Clinical photograph depicts accessory nipple with adjacent homogeneous hypoechoic US nodule along milk line, exemplifying supernumerary breast tissue presentation supporting the diagnosis;18823:US reveals discrete oval lymph nodes with eccentric cortical thickening >3mm, round shape, hypoechoic cortex, and preserved fatty hila, distinctly different from the multi-tubular anechoic ductal pattern in lactating breast tissue, aiding differentiation from lymphadenopathy

2761:MRI demonstrates small area of high signal intensity on T1-weighted images (Image 2, black arrow) suppressed on fat-saturated T1 sequence (Image 5, white arrow), confirming diagnostic fat content in ovarian mature cystic teratoma, directly matching the target case’s T1 hyperintensity and fat suppression.;12570:MRI shows characteristic hyperintense fat globule on T1 and T2-weighted sequences (Images 3 and 4) floating in cystic ovarian mass (dermoid cyst), identical to the target’s intracystic nondependent fat-fluid level and signal characteristics.;14177:CECT in prone position clearly depicts fat-fluid level with fat layering dependently (Image 7), proving mobile fat in teratoma and supporting the dynamic floating heterogeneous solid-fat part observed in the target MRI.;15364:CT illustrates multiple fat-fluid levels, solid/liquid fat-fluid interfaces, and projecting calcified Rokitansky nodule (Image 3, triangle), features diagnostic of mature teratoma akin to target’s heterogeneous floating solid part with fat signal.;11811:CT reveals complex cystic right ovarian mass with distinct fat attenuation areas (red arrows, Images 1 and 2), confirming fat-containing mature teratoma and reinforcing the key fat diagnostic criterion over differentials like endometrioma.

5522:MRI shows T2 hyperintense cystic lesion in thigh muscle with hypointense membranes and daughter cysts on T1, matching the multicystic high T2 low T1 with septa and daughter cysts in target Primary Muscle Hydatid Disease;15931:MRI demonstrates large multiloculated cystic lesion hyperintense on T2-weighted, hypointense T1 with internal small daughter cysts and minimal peripheral rim enhancement post-contrast, identical to target imaging features confirming hydatid cyst;16807:US and MRI reveal multiple ovoid cystic lesions with daughter cysts clusters, echogenic debris, detached membranes, double-line sign, and septal enhancement, classic for hydatid helping confirm the diagnosis over differentials;11775:US shows cyst within cyst pattern with multiple smaller cysts, MRI multilocular cystic in muscle with slight enhancement, shares multilocular cystic appearance and cyst-in-cyst sign diagnostic for hydatid;6515:MRI shows large multiloculated cystic mass with gas in locules subcutaneous in thigh, lacks daughter cysts and shows gas distinguishing abscess from the well-defined intramuscular multicystic no-gas hydatid in target;17597:MRI T2 high signal multiseptated subcutaneous cyst with internal hypointense rounded formations on T1 and wall/septal enhancement, similar septated cystic pattern with internal structures supporting hydatid diagnosis

11028:Fibrolipomatous hamartoma of median nerve: axial T1/T2 images show classic coaxial cable appearance with multiple low-signal tubular nerve fascicles surrounded by high-signal fat (suppresses on fat-sat), spaghetti-string longitudinally; stark contrast to target case small intraneural lesion lacking fat components, instead showing high T1/GRE blooming hemorrhage confirming vascular nature;11774:Schwannoma arising from median nerve: fusiform mass hypointense T1, markedly hyperintense T2/FS, homogeneous strong post-Gd enhancement; differentiates from target by homogeneous enhancement (vs heterogeneous), absence of blooming artifact/hemorrhage, and larger fusiform shape without iso-high T1 foci;16243:Partially thrombosed AV malformation abutting sciatic nerve: US shows hypoechoic lesion with arterial color/power Doppler flow adjacent thickened nerve; MRI T2 hyperintense abnormal vascular channels causing nerve thickening/hyperintensity - similar T2 hyper/vascularity but extrinsic location, arterial flow, no intralesional bloom distinguishes from pure intraneural venous malformation;4265:Facial nerve hemangioma at geniculate: T2 hyperintense intraneural enhancing lesion in bony canal with CT honeycomb osteolysis/trabeculae; shares strong enhancement and T2 hyperintensity but bony remodeling/spicules absent in target and no hemorrhage bloom differentiate;1308:Thenar schwannoma (median-innervated): T1 intermediate, T2/STIR hyperintense encapsulated mass with avid heterogeneous enhancement and central hypointense focus on post-Gd; contrasts with target by larger size, muscle-intrinsic location, lack of GRE blooming despite some enhancement heterogeneity

14073:Volume rendering images demonstrate superdominant RCA extending posteriorly along the base of the heart and left AV groove to supply lateral LV wall, similar to retro-aortic LCx course in target case, helping confirm extensive posterior supply without separate LCx origin;4847:Volume rendering shows anomalous single ostium origin of RCA from left sinus with anterior course to ascending aorta (prepulmonic-like), mirroring the prepulmonic LAD course in target, without slit-like orifice or intramural segment confirming benign variant;16640:Axial MIP clearly depicts common origin from right sinus with LM coursing interarterially between aorta and pulmonary trunk, a malignant feature distinguishing ACAOS from the target benign prepulmonic/retro-aortic mono coronary without interarterial course;11134:Axial MIP reveals RCA interarterial between Ao and PA, arising from common proximal trunk with left sinus origin, slit-like small calibre opening and acute angulation at origin - malignant features absent in target mono coronary;5946:Axial images and 3D VR illustrate separate RCA ostium from left sinus with interarterial course between aorta and pulmonary artery, differentiating malignant ACAOS interarterial pattern from target non-malignant features;6587:3D volume rendering and MPR depict RCA anomalous origin from left sinus with inter-arterial course, acute angle takeoff and intramural-like segment, key differentiators from target mono coronary lacking these high-risk features

17318:Primary splenic DLBCL: US shows solitary large heterogeneous slightly hypoechoic mass with hypovascularity and traversing vessel, MRI T1 isointense T2 slightly hyperintense with arterial hypoenhancement and progressive heterogeneous delayed enhancement, confirming typical imaging of solitary splenic lymphoma mass as in target case.;1484:Splenic large cell lymphoma: CT depicts enlarged inhomogeneous enhancing spleen with ill-defined margins and perisplenic collections, mirroring heterogeneous splenomegaly and mass borders in target NHL.;2357:Primary splenic abscess: US large hypoechoic heterogeneous lesion, CT solitary non-enhancing hypodense mass; differentiates from target by uniform fluid-like low density without peripheral solid/target sign/central necrotic cavity pathology.;9080:Splenic bacterial abscess: US hypo-anechoic round with debris, MRI T1 hyperintense proteinaceous content T2 mixed fluid thin rim enhancement no internal enhancement; contrasts solid heterogeneous T2 decreased center (necrosis) without rim in target lymphoma.;9426:SANT: Round splenic mass CT iso-hypo non-contrast hypoarterial inhomogeneous portal iso-delayed with moderate PET; differentiates progressive vascular pattern from lymphoma poor enhancement central necrosis.;16827:SANT: MRI T1 iso-hypo heterogeneous T2 predominantly low signal central high spoke-wheel peripheral-central enhancement; distinguishes fibrous low T2 progressive fill-in from target heterogeneous necrotic target sign.

18420:CT demonstrates lytic metastatic lesions with faint medullary borders in sternum and femoral head in a child with stage IV neuroblastoma, mirroring the extensive permeative medullary bone destruction observed on the target case humerus radiograph.;13144:Contrast-enhanced CT shows sunray spiculation of the skull vault underlying a large extracranial soft tissue mass extending intracranially in neuroblastoma skull metastasis, exemplifying the aggressive discontinuous periosteal reaction and associated soft tissue mass seen in the target humerus MRI.;8113:AP radiograph reveals subtle osteolytic lesion with poorly demarcated margins in the proximal humeral diaphysis in an infant with acute lymphoblastic leukemia, contrasting with the more extensive permeative pattern and prominent periosteal reaction in the target; MRI shows multifocal skeletal marrow lesions low T1 high T2 distinguishing diffuse leukemic infiltration.;2563:Plain radiographs depict poorly defined destructive lesion of proximal femur with multilayered onion-skin periosteal new bone in child Ewing sarcoma, differing from the discontinuous periosteal reaction in target; MRI confirms extensive medullary involvement and large soft tissue mass.;12303:AP radiograph of humerus shows geographic to moth-eaten lobulated osteolytic lesion proximal meta-diaphysis with discrete periosteal reaction in subacute osteomyelitis; MRI reveals multiple rim-enhancing fluid collections with penumbra sign and fat globules, differentiating abscesses from the solid heterogeneous enhancing bone/soft tissue lesion in target NB met.;11625:Pelvic radiographs show expanded irregular partially sclerotic right iliac wing in infant Ewing sarcoma; MRI T2 demonstrates lamellar periosteal pattern and radiating striated pattern with diffuse parosteal soft tissue enhancement, highlighting distinct Ewing-specific periosteal features vs target discontinuous pattern.;19119:Radiograph tibia proximal diaphysis moth-eaten mixed lytic-sclerotic permeative lesion with permeated cortex pathological fracture interrupted lamellar periosteal and soft tissue swelling in toddler B-lymphoblastic lymphoma; MRI T1 hypointense heterogeneous STIR hyperintense marrow/extraosseous mass cortical breakthrough heterogeneous enhancement, closely mimicking target imaging but differentiated by pathology.

18459:ADEM case with CT hypodense right thalamic lesion and bilateral cerebellar lesions, T2/FLAIR hypersignal in thalamus and cerebellum with surrounding less intense hypersignal, peripheral incomplete ring enhancement on post-contrast T1 - confirms deep gray matter involvement and characteristic incomplete ring enhancement seen in target case, with follow-up regression similar to target;17966:ADEM with subtle CT hypodensities in dorsal pons and bilateral MCP, symmetric T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in bilateral internal capsules, dorsal midbrain, pons, MCP matching target CT hypointensities and patchy confluent hyperintensities in midbrain/basal ganglia/internal capsules;8615:Adult ADEM showing initial focal T2 hyperintensity left occipital progressing to extensive multifocal white matter lesions in brain and spinal cord with variable enhancement, then improvement post-steroids - illustrates monophasic disseminated pattern distinguishing from relapsing MS;15617:Tumefactive demyelinating lesion with T1 hypointense T2/FLAIR hyperintense frontal lesions, open ring enhancement on post-contrast (U-shaped), low central rCBV favoring demyelination over glioma/paraneoplastic in differential - similar ring enhancement morphology to target incomplete ring;18443:MOGAD with large confluent poorly demarcated T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in bilateral thalamus, basal ganglia, midbrain, pons, extensive subcortical white matter - similar symmetric deep gray/brainstem/white matter involvement but more fluffy extensive pattern helps differentiate from typical smaller periventricular MS lesions;6530:Pseudotumoral demyelinating with large poorly defined T2 hyperintense posterior periventricular/subcortical lesions without mass effect, serial peripheral enhancement peaking then resolving - demonstrates large confluent lesions with variable ring-like enhancement and resolution favoring acute demyelinating over glioma;8289:Tumefactive demyelination with large subcortical parieto-temporal T1 hypo T2/FLAIR hyperintense lesions minimal mass effect, thin incomplete open ring enhancement open towards cortex - matches target incomplete ring enhancement distinguishing from complete ring abscess/tumor

16849:Rectal US shows hypoechoic tumor confined to submucosa matching target EUS; MRI T1 hyperintense endoluminal lobulated mass at anorectal junction (yellow arrows Images 1-4) due to melanin; restricted diffusion (high b1000/low ADC, Images 5-6) - confirms characteristic melanoma imaging pattern;9271:MRI axial/sagittal shows circumferential intermediate-signal wall thickening of entire anal canal (Images 1-8) with inguinal LN; follow-up exophytic progression/necrosis (Images 9-14) - differentiates anal SCC by infiltrative morphology lacking T1 hyperintensity/polypoid shape/low T2/restricted DWI of melanoma;1586:T2 MRI sagittal/axial shows 4cm polypoid lower rectal tumor (arrows Images 1-2) with intermediate-high T2 signal, no muscle invasion - distinguishes rectal adenocarcinoma by higher T2 signal, absence of T1 hyperintensity/restricted diffusion;18718:MRI T2 coronal/axial hyperintense heterogeneous intramural polypoid lesion distal rectum (arrows Images 1-2); no DWI restriction (Images 3-4) - differentiates haemorrhoid by vascular T2 hyperintensity vs melanomas low T2/solid hypoechoic/restricted diffusion

18034:Coronal STIR images show marked hyperintense signal in the right gluteal muscles indicative of denervation edema, mirroring the STIR hyperintensity in right gluteus medius minimus and TFL in the target case confirming subacute denervation pattern.;19188:Axial T1-weighted image shows high signal intensity in left gluteus minimus consistent with fatty degeneration, similar to the mild increased T1 signal indicating fatty changes in targets right gluteus minimus medius and TFL.;18854:Proton density fat saturation sequences demonstrate high signal in right gluteus medius and minimus tendons at greater trochanter insertion, akin to the edema-like high signal on STIR in targets abductor muscles.;10762:Axial and coronal T1-w images show increased signal in lateral compartment muscles from fatty infiltration with no STIR edema, contrasting the subacute stage in target (edema + mild fatty) vs chronic denervation.;17825:MRI axial T1/T2 show enlarged right piriformis muscle with hyperintense abscess lesion and rim enhancement on post-gad fatsat, distinguishing focal piriformis pathology compressing sciatic nerve from the indirect muscle denervation without mass in target case.

13654:Contrast-enhanced CT shows severely distended gallbladder with large intraluminal air-fluid level, intramural gas (arrows along wall), absent wall enhancement indicating gangrene, pericholecystic fat stranding and perihepatic free fluid - matches target gangrenous cholecystitis with mural gas inclusions, wall disruption, pericholecystitis.;16002:Portal phase CT demonstrates mural thickening and hypoenhancement of gallbladder wall with abundant intraluminal gas, aerobilia in left biliary tree and cystic duct, gallstone - shares target features of intraluminal gas, pneumobilia in CBD, severe inflammation.;2969:CT axial images reveal markedly distended gallbladder filled with air in lumen and intramural gas collections, extensive pericholecystic fluid/inflammation - confirms gangrenous cholecystitis pattern with pericholecystitis as in target.;10390:Multiplanar CT shows inflamed thick-walled gallbladder with intramural air along anterior/inferomedial margins, pericholecystic fluid, extra-luminal air locules anteriorly indicating perforation - key intramural gas and pericholecystic changes matching target.;13294:Plain film curvilinear gas RUQ (GB wall), US thickened echogenic wall with intramural gas and stones, CT fluid level in distended GB with gas in wall/lumen, reticular pericholecystic fat stranding - classic emphysematous cholecystitis imaging aiding confirmation.;1150:CT depicts gas within gallbladder wall and lumen (arrows), associated pericystic, perihepatic fluid collections - directly mirrors target mural and intraluminal gas with pericholecystitis.;1489:Conventional tomography fluid-filled GB with air in wall, CECT thickened GB wall intramural air, air in intrapancreatic choledochal duct (pneumobilia) - shares intramural gas and biliary gas extension.

13232:CT axial shows decreased L5-S1 intervertebral space, endplate irregularity, and anterior paravertebral soft tissue thickening; MRI sagittal/axial T1/T2 demonstrate low T1/high T2 signal in disc/endplates with enhancement, anterior paravertebral abscess, and fistula tract connecting to sigmoid colon ulcer - directly analogous to duodenal fistula tract opacified by oral contrast leading to paravertebral abscess/disc spaces in target case, confirming bowel perforation as cause of spondylodiscitis;19122:CT coronal/axial shows gas bubbles (arrows) in bilateral psoas muscles and within L3 vertebral body; MRI axial T2 hyperintense multiple round collections in psoas/paraspinal muscles, post-contrast T1 enhancing lesions, sagittal T1 subtle enhancement L2-L5 vertebrae/discs with T2/STIR hyperintensity - matches gas-containing paravertebral collection surrounding aorta L2-L4 extending to disc/epidural spaces in target, confirming pyogenic spondylodiscitis pattern;4822:CT axial shows multiple arrows to free intraperitoneal gas indicating perforated viscus (prepyloric ulcer), L1 inferior endplate destruction with epidural/psoas collections; coronal psoas abscess extension, amorphous peripheral calcifications in psoas abscess - demonstrates association of bowel perforation with spondylodiscitis/psoas abscess but differentiates TB via calcifications from pyogenic Strep anginosus etiology in target;4857:MRI sagittal T2/STIR hyperintense L1-L2 disc space and vertebral bodies with anterior epidural high signal; axial T2 large anterior epidural collection; post-contrast enhancement of VB/meninges/epidural; CT sagittal/axial extensive anterior/lateral osteolytic erosion L1/L2 with thin posterior wall and microcalcifications in disc - similar aggressive pyogenic bone/disc destruction and epidural involvement as in target paravertebral/disc extension

13203:Coronal and axial CT temporal bone demonstrate bilateral hypodense demineralized plaques involving the oval windows and surrounding cochlea with thickened stapes footplate (0.8 mm), distinguishing otosclerosis spongiotic changes from solid bony obliteration of the oval window niche seen in congenital atresia.;2682:Axial and coronal CT show thickened stapes footplate/annular ligament, osteolytic focus anterior to oval window, and otosclerotic plaque obliterating round window niche; contrasts hypodense spongiotic bone with hyperdense bony plate of oval window atresia.;2685:Axial CT temporal bone reveals incudostapedial joint dislocation (disconnected lenticular process of incus from stapes capitulum), with normal oval window niche and stapes footplate, differentiating ossicular discontinuity from oval window atresia.;8090:HRCT axial and coronal views show right external auditory canal and tympanic membrane replaced by bone (aural atresia), but normal middle ear cavity, ossicles including stapes at oval window, distinguishing EAC atresia from isolated oval window atresia.;8672:HRCT demonstrates bilateral complete external auditory canal atresia with osseous atresia plates at expected tympanic membrane sites, soft tissue closure laterally, but normal bilateral middle/inner ear structures including stapes at fenestrated oval windows, contrasting atresia location.

959:Warthin tumor parotid MRI demonstrates low T2 signal intensity lesion (dark mass on axial T2 images 1-2), differing from target acinic cell carcinoma T2 hyperintensity, aiding differentiation from Warthin tumor.;1128:Pleomorphic adenoma parotid: T1 hypointense (images 2-4), heterogeneous T2 hyperintense (image 5), intense heterogeneous enhancement post-Gd (images 6-8), shares features with target solid enhancing parotid mass but highlights overlap/challenges in distinguishing low-grade malignancy.;16845:Pleomorphic adenoma: MRI T1 hypointense (image 2), T2 hyperintense (images 3-4), marked diffusion restriction (image 7 high DWI signal), progressive enhancement with fibrous capsule halo (images 5-6); similar to target low ADC/restricted diffusion/vivid enhancement, but capsule distinguishes benign while confirming cellularity sign for acinic ca.;4957:Multiple Warthin tumors parotid: cystic hypodense lesions on CT (images 1-3), multicentric cystic hyperintense on T2 MRI with thin enhancing walls (images 10-17), contrasts solid heterogeneous no-cyst target lesion, differentiating from cystic Warthin.;7748:Parapharyngeal pleomorphic adenoma extending to deep parotid lobe: well-marginated T2 hyperintense mass on MRI (bright on presumed T2 in images 2-4), hypointense T1 enhancing moderately; matches target deep lobe location and signal but long slow growth favors benign.

12459:CT axial images show complete replacement of pancreatic parenchyma by uniformly low attenuation fat-density tissue (-115 HU, visually matching surrounding fat) surrounding splenic vein and vessels with preserved architecture, MRI confirms fatty tissue with hyperintense signal and visible pancreaticobiliary ducts coursing through - directly confirms the uniform fatty replacement of pancreas body/tail as in target case with mass effect.;9519:Unenhanced and contrast CT images demonstrate near-total replacement of pancreatic parenchyma by low attenuation fat throughout the bed, no normal glandular tissue, but distinguished by multiple intraductal calculi in head - confirms extensive lipomatosis pattern while calculi differentiate from pure lipomatous pseudohypertrophy without stones.;10028:CT shows well-defined focal hypodense fat-attenuation mass (HU -90 to -100) at neck-body junction surrounded by normal pancreas, MRI T1/T2 hyperintense with signal dropout on STIR fat suppression - differentiates focal discrete lipoma from diffuse enlarged fatty pseudohypertrophy with mass effect on adjacent structures.;16955:CT hypodense sharply demarcated lesion anterior head pancreas, MRI focal homogeneous signal loss on T1 fat-suppressed and out-of-phase sequences confirming focal fatty infiltration - distinguishes focal uneven lipomatosis from diffuse body/tail involvement and enlargement in target.;13671:CT demonstrates abrupt truncation of pancreas at neck with absent body/tail, tiny calcifications in head; MRI confirms absence without fatty replacement, short Wirsung duct and cysts in head remnant - differentiates pancreatic agenesis (empty bed, no mass effect) from fatty pseudohypertrophy.;17140:CT heterogeneous solid retroperitoneal mass with central necrosis, IVC invasion, duodenum displacement, no fat density uniformity - differentiates malignant retroperitoneal liposarcoma from benign uniform pancreatic fat replacement.

11172:Chest X-ray shows small subdiaphragmatic lucency (pneumoperitoneum) identical to target case Fig.1; abdominal X-rays demonstrate air under diaphragm with suggestion of free fluid; CT axial images show free intra-peritoneal air bubbles and hypodense fluid collections perihepatically/perisplenically; sagittal CT reveals contrast leak from pylorus akin to target duodenal bulb discontinuity confirming hydropneumoperitoneum from upper GI perforation;2845:Erect chest X-ray displays large subdiaphragmatic air crescent (massive pneumoperitoneum) matching target Fig.1; supine AXR shows Rigler sign (free air outlining both sides of bowel wall) supporting pneumoperitoneum diagnosis;16749:CT axial/sagittal/coronal show large lesser sac collections with internal air-fluid levels similar to target hydropneumoperitoneum; no free peritonitis but contained perforation pattern from duodenal ulcer helps confirm possible evolution;14507:CT multiplanar demonstrates gas-containing pancreaticoduodenal abscess with focal communication/fistula (arrows) from proximal duodenal wall to collection, wall thickening/edema mirroring target CT Figs.3-5 duodenal bulb discontinuity and edema;13942:CT axial reveals linear hyperdense fish bone traversing duodenal wall with adjacent small air bubble and fat stranding, distinguishing foreign body perforation (differential B) from ulcer by presence of foreign body without massive pneumoperitoneum or wall thickening;16839:CT lung/soft tissue windows show large volume subdiaphragmatic free air (pneumoperitoneum) without ascites, stranding, or focal bowel wall defect/thickening unlike target which has hydropneumoperitoneum and duodenal discontinuity distinguishing idiopathic spontaneous (differential F);16860:CT shows SMA thrombosis, long segment thin-walled poorly enhancing distal ileum with dehiscence/perforation and peri-ileal air-fluid collection; differentiates bowel ischemia (differential D) by vascular findings, ileal location, lack of focal duodenal changes

9105:Contrast-enhanced CT shows broad irregular appendiceal mass with thickened enhancing walls and diffuse surrounding adipose tissue thickening extending to pelvis, matching target case irregular circumferential wall thickening and mesenteric fat stranding, confirming appendiceal neoplastic pattern;3417:CT demonstrates large cystic appendiceal mass with discrete thin wall enhancement, small amount of air and oral contrast in lumen, limited fat reaction - differentiates mucocele/mucinous neoplasms by prominent hypodense cystic lumen unlike solid irregular thickening in target nonmucinous adenocarcinoma;17497:CT reveals hyperdense caecal/ascending colon wall thickening, pericaecal fat stranding, hyperattenuating diverticula, with normal non-inflamed appendix - distinguishes caecal diverticulitis by caecum-centered inflammation and spared appendix absent in target;1602:CT shows enlarged appendix (~10mm short axis) with uniform wall thickening and prominent periappendiceal fat stranding, without irregular contours or pericecal nodes seen in target, typical for uncomplicated appendicitis differentiation;13126:CT depicts long tubular blind-ending low-attenuation fluid-filled structure arising from cecum (10x3cm) with smooth thin walls, no fat stranding or nodes - classic mucocele differentiated by cystic dilatation lacking target solid irregular wall thickening;12940:CT axial/coronal shows solitary enhancing caecal diverticulum with adjacent wall thickening, fat stranding, small free fluid and extraluminal air bubbles indicating microperforation, normal appendix - differentiates by focal diverticular signs without appendiceal involvement;10592:Portal phase CT shows mildly enlarged appendix (7mm) with terminal mucosal discontinuity (perforation), peritoneal enhancement and ascites, but large infiltrative mesenteric root mass - dual pathology helps differentiate isolated appendiceal tumor from complicated cases

16243:US shows hypoechoic lesion in posterior thigh with prominent color Doppler flow signals (arterial and venous labeled A/V), MRI demonstrates serpiginous abnormal vascular channels abutting thickened sciatic nerve with fatty muscle atrophy - mirrors target case US inhomogeneous muscle mass with Doppler signals and MRI vascular replacement of muscle confirming high-flow vascular malformation;17667:US crooked hypoechoic interdigital lesion with color Doppler aliasing and spectral low-resistance high-velocity arterial flow (peak 274 cm/s), MRI T1 hypo mass with central nidus of linear hypointense flow voids on DP FS - classic high-flow AVM imaging distinguishing from low-flow VMs or sarcomas lacking flow voids;13949:Plain film and CT show cortical thickening and multiple lytic punch-out lesions in tibia/fibula without permeative pattern, MRI depicts abnormal serpiginous vessels in posterior calf muscles extending interosseously with T2 FS flow voids and early arterial enhancement - parallels target femoral diaphysis sclerosis/thickening and flow voids due to high-flow hyperemia;15905:US multiple tortuous anechoic tubular channels with power Doppler complete color saturation, high-velocity pulsatile arterial waveform (spectral broadening) and arterialized venous flow; MRI muscle infiltration with aneurysmal dilatations - direct match to target US well-defined squeezable mass with clear Doppler signals confirming high-flow pattern vs solid sarcomas;14433:CTA extensive dilated serpiginous arterial-venous nidus in upper limb with multiple AV fistulae, intraosseous hypervascularity causing prominent nutrient grooves, cortical erosions, and bone deformity; MRI medullary signal voids - demonstrates bone remodeling from high-flow shunting similar to target CT femoral cortical thickening

3814:CT shows multiple small calcified densities in omentum and peritoneum matching the calcified mesenteric adenopathies in target case, with jejunal wall thickening and subserosal high-density collection consistent with GI TB;4430:Gastrograffin study demonstrates pyloroduodenal fistula with extraluminal contrast and CT shows peritoneal gas collection adjacent to duodenum, mirroring the tubular hypodense fistulous tract and pneumoperitoneum gas bubbles in target;2095:Contrast CT reveals concentric mural thickening of caecum/ileum with adjacent mesenteric stranding and small regional nodes, exemplifying ileocaecal TB pattern with peritoneal involvement distinguishing from Crohn disease;680:CT depicts mesenteric masslike conglomerate of enlarged lymph nodes surrounding SMA with surrounding fat stranding, similar to hypodense adenopathies and remarkable mesenteric fat inflammation in target TB;18267:CECT axial sections show calcified mesenteric/retroperitoneal lymph nodes (circled high-density spots) and asymmetric enhancing bowel wall thickening at ileocaecal junction, key features confirming TB diagnosis like target calcified adenopathies;11776:CT demonstrates irregular omental thickening (omental cake), linear small bowel mesenteric thickening with crowded vessels, and small homogeneous mesenteric nodes, reflecting the mesenteric inflammatory changes and adenopathy seen in target intestinal TB

9439:Axial and coronal contrast-enhanced CT shows marked annular tumoural thickening of the ascending colon with luminal narrowing and multiple hypoattenuating liver lesions, confirming amoebic colitis/ameboma can produce similar concentric right colon wall thickening as target case;17728:CT and MRI demonstrate subtle but persistent caecal wall thickening, biopsy-confirmed amoebic colitis - matches target caecum involvement with mural edema;17079:Coronal and sagittal CT reveals diffuse wall thickening of ascending, transverse, and descending colon with thumbprinting (submucosal oedema), right pericolonic fat stranding, and ascites (spared ileum); distinguishes CMV colitis by extension beyond hepatic flexure;5314:CT depicts bowel wall thickening and enhancement of the cecum with adjacent fat edema, characteristic of typhlitis - similar initial right colon findings to aid differentiation in immunocompromised;8844:Axial CT shows diffuse heterogeneous cecal wall thickening (4-20 mm) with intramural low-density areas, pericolic edema, and ascites extending to ileum/transverse colon; neutropenic colitis differentiates by broader involvement and heterogeneity;10393:Post-contrast CT shows diffuse mural thickening with target/water halo sign (enhanced mucosa, thick hypodense submucosa) in right colon to hepatic flexure, ascites - mimics infectious colitis imaging pattern;7816:CT demonstrates pancolonic circumferential wall thickening with target and accordion signs from cecum to rectum, pericolic stranding - pseudomembranous colitis contrasts segmental right-sided involvement;17497:CT illustrates slight hyperdense wall thickening of caecum/proximal ascending colon, mesenteric fat stranding, and hyperdense inflamed diverticula - caecal diverticulitis distinguished by diverticular signs

8494:MRI demonstrates hyperintense fluid collection in right iliacus muscle adjacent to SI joint with surrounding marrow signal changes in sacrum and ilium, mirroring the adjacent muscle high signal and sacral bone involvement seen in target case;10303:CT shows cortical erosions and irregularities at left SI joint involving sacrum and ilium with low-density abscess collections in iliopsoas, obturator, and gluteus minimus muscles, matching cortical loss at SI joint and adjacent muscle thickening in target;17605:MRI T2 hyperintensity in right sacral and iliac bone marrow adjacent to SI joint with peripheral enhancing abscesses in iliacus muscle, directly comparable to target hyperintense sacral lesion with soft tissue collection and enhancement;18506:MRI PDw fat-sat shows central low-signal bone sequestrum surrounded by hyperintense marrow edema and cortical cloacae with adjacent vastus muscle high signal myositis, exemplifying the low-signal central sequestrum and muscle involvement in target sacral osteomyelitis;4857:MRI STIR hyperintense bone marrow edema in vertebrae with epidural high signal and post-gad enhancement, CT cortical osteolysis, similar pyogenic pattern to target bone destruction and enhancement;14951:Whole-body STIR MRI shows multiple hyperintense bone lesions including S4/S5 vertebrae and iliac wing without central sequestrum or rim-enhancing abscess, helping differentiate multifocal CRMO from pyogenic sacral osteomyelitis with sequestrum

6879:CT shows large heterogeneous intrarenal mass with hypodense necrotic areas and inhomogeneous contrast enhancement, no visible calcifications - confirms typical Wilms tumor imaging pattern of heterogeneous soft tissue density with necrosis matching the target extrarenal Wilms mass;17695:Contrast CT demonstrates multiple heterogeneously enhancing masses replacing the left kidney with non-enhancing hypodense necrotic regions, no calcifications - identical heterogeneous necrotic pattern to target, supporting Wilms histology despite renal origin;5926:Pelvic CT reveals large heterogeneous enhancing presacral mass with central necrosis but small punctate calcifications visible - distinguishes neuroblastoma by presence of calcifications absent in target Wilms;9384:US and CT show huge heterogeneous abdominopelvic mass arising above bladder with necrotic components and prominent intralesional/perilesional vascularity evidenced by collateral veins - similar pelvic heterogeneous necrosis but marked hypervascularity differentiates alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma;12237:US depicts heterogeneous lobulated solid mass at bladder neck with high vascular flow on color Doppler, confirmed on CT - pelvic location similar but intravesical origin and intense vascularity distinguish embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma from extrarenal Wilms;702:CT illustrates large heterogeneous left renal mass distorting parenchyma with mixed enhancement - classic Wilms appearance mirroring lobulated heterogeneous texture and necrosis of target case;6899:US shows echogenic retroperitoneal mass with prominent internal vascular flow on Doppler, CT enhancing with clear margins - smaller size and marked vascularity help differentiate extra-adrenal neuroblastoma

18687:CT shows well-defined iso-hyperdense roundish mass in left upper eyelid with heterogeneous post-contrast enhancement similar to target Merkel cell ca; MRI T1 hypointense T2 hyperintense exophytic lesion with smooth margins and diffusion restriction matching the hydrated smooth-margin appearance in target case - confirms imaging pattern for malignant eyelid tumor;583:MR images demonstrate superficial cutaneous violaceous nodular lesions with surrounding inflammatory changes on T2-weighted imaging, consistent with Merkel cell carcinoma appearance, similar to the superficial purple rapidly-growing eyelid nodule in target case;16278:CT axial shows heterogeneously enhancing solid mass involving left upper eyelid and conjunctiva displacing globe anteriorly; MRI T2 hyperintense mass - shares exophytic eyelid mass with T2 hyperintensity like target, neuroendocrine tumor helps confirm aggressive small cell pattern;17957:CT demonstrates infiltrative periorbital soft-tissue mass involving both eyelids with heterogeneous enhancement, central necrosis, and medial orbital wall bone destruction displacing optic nerve - distinguishes Merkel cell by lack of bone erosion and well-defined margins without deep infiltration;16230:Contrast-enhanced CT shows homogeneously enhancing solid retrobulbar orbital mass; MRI iso-hypointense T1, hypointense T2 with diffusion restriction and muscle/optic sheath invasion - differentiates from superficial eyelid exophytic T2 hyperintense Merkel cell by deeper location and T2 hypointensity

11941:CT shows well-defined unilocular expansile cystic lesion in anterior mandible with cortical thinning and breach, mirroring the target case’s CT cystic unilocular mass with bone cortex thinning and defects;13229:CT bone window: expansile hypodense lesion with cortical thinning, loculations, and soft tissue window reveals peripheral enhancing septum akin to target’s enhancing mural nodule on medial wall;15243:MRI demonstrates multilocular solid/cystic mass with vivid enhancement of papillary solid projections and irregular margins, cortical thinning/erosion on CT, confirming enhancing solid components in ameloblastoma vs pure cyst;18495:CT exhibits cortical expansion, scalloping, thinning with soap-bubble multiloculated expansile lesion; enhancing solid papillary projections on CT/MRI match target’s intramural enhancing nodule and scalloped cystic borders;10867:CT/MRI show polycystic expansile lesion in posterior body/ramus with cortical deformation, fluid and parenchymatous components with heterogeneous enhancement, similar location and mixed cystic-solid features;16132:CBCT/MRI: expansile radiolucent lesion with lingual cortical scalloping and buccal breach, T2 hyperintense cystic with weak thin peripheral rim enhancement only (no mural nodule), differentiates OKC from ameloblastoma’s prominent intramural nodule
